summary.0: History is a continuous process, and it is not always easy to distinguish when one period ends and another begins. The history of modern India began with the arrival of the Europeans in the 15th century, even before the Mughals established their empire. The decline of the Roman Empire in the 7th century led to a decline in direct contact between Europe and India, affecting the accessibility of Indian commodities like spices, calicoes, silk, and precious stones. Constantinople fell to the Ottoman Turks in 1453, further impacting trade.
summary.1: After the fall of Constantinople in 1453, Arab Muslim intermediaries controlled the trade routes to India. The Europeans, eager to find a direct sea route to India, made great advances in ship-building and navigation. They wanted to reach the unknown corners of the East and meet the demand for oriental luxury goods, which increased with the economic development of many regions of Europe.
summary.2: As prosperity grew in Europe, so did the demand for luxury goods from the East. Venice and Genoa were too small to compete with the Ottoman Turks, but the north Europeans were ready to aid Portugal and Spain with money and men. Portugal took on the leadership in resisting Islam and exploring new routes to India, with Prince Henry of Portugal leading the way as an obsessed navigator.
summary.3: Prince Henry of Portugal was obsessed with finding a sea route to India to bypass Muslim domination of the Mediterranean. Pope Nicholas V gave him permission to navigate to India, but he died before it could happen. In 1497, Portugal and Spain divided the non-Christian world between them, with Portugal claiming everything to the east of an imaginary line in the Atlantic. Portuguese navigator Bartholomew Dias rounded the Cape of Good Hope in 1487, and ten years later, an expedition of Portuguese ships arrived in India in May 1498.
summary.4: The arrival of Vasco Da Gama's three ships in Calicut in May 1498 changed Indian history. The Hindu ruler welcomed him, but Arab traders were worried about Portuguese dominance. The Indian Ocean trading system had many participants, but none sought overwhelming dominance.
summary.5: The Portuguese wanted to control the profitable eastern trade by excluding competitors, especially the Arabs. Vasco da Gama stayed in India for three months and returned to Portugal with a rich cargo, selling it at a huge profit. Other European merchants were tempted to come to India and trade directly. Pedro Alvarez Cabral negotiated and established a factory at Calicut in September 1500, but there was an incident of conflict resulting in the death of several Portuguese.
summary.6: In response to the Portuguese factory attack, Cabral seized Arab merchant ships and bombarded Calicut. He later made treaties with Cochin and Cannanore. When Vasco da Gama returned in 1501, he sought to exclude Arab merchants, but faced resistance from the Zamorin due to his hostility towards them. The landing of da Gama in 1498 marked a new era in world history.
summary.7: The Portuguese wanted to weaken their enemies, the Muslims, Arabs, and Turks, by finding a new sea-route to India. They hoped to break the monopoly of the Arabs and Turks over the trade in eastern goods and explore Africa to find the legendary Prester John, who they believed would help them attack the Muslims from two sides.
summary.8: The Portuguese had multiple objectives in opening a sea-route to India. They wanted to weaken the Muslims, Arabs, and Turks who were enemies of Christianity and posed a threat to Europe. They also aimed to break the monopoly of the Arabs and Turks over the trade in eastern goods and hoped to find Prester John's kingdom to attack the Muslims from two sides. The Portuguese set up trading factories at Cannanore, Calicut, and Cochin, and gradually got permission to fortify these centres. Francisco De Almeida was appointed as governor to consolidate their position and destroy Muslim trade by seizing Aden, Ormuz, and Malacca.
summary.9: Francisco De Almeida was appointed as the governor of India by the King of Portugal in 1505. He was tasked with consolidating the Portuguese position in India and destroying Muslim trade. He was also advised to build fortresses at various trade centres. However, he faced opposition from the Zamorin and a threat from the Mameluke Sultan of Egypt. In 1507, the Portuguese squadron was defeated in a naval battle off Diu, but Almeida avenged his defeat the next year. Alfonso de Albuquerque succeeded Almeida and established bases overlooking all the entrances to the Indian Ocean, securing strategic control for Portugal.
summary.10: Albuquerque established Portuguese bases in East Africa, off the Red Sea, at Ormuz, in Malabar, and at Malacca. He introduced a permit system for other ships and controlled major ship-building centers. Albuquerque acquired Goa from the Sultan of Bijapur in 1510 and abolished sati. However, his policy of persecuting Muslims was a drawback.
summary.11: Albuquerque persecuted Muslims to eliminate their commercial interests in the East. He strengthened Goa's fortifications and encouraged Portuguese men to take Indian wives to establish a permanent population. They became landlords, introduced new crops, and settled as artisans and traders, considering their new settlements as home.
summary.12: Nino da Cunha became governor of Portuguese interests in India in 1529 and moved the government headquarters to Goa a year later. Bahadur Shah of Gujarat gave the Portuguese the island of Bassein and promised them a base in Diu in 1534, but their relationship soured when Humayun withdrew from Gujarat in 1536. The Portuguese killed the ruler of Gujarat in 1537 after negotiations failed.
summary.13: In the Deccan, kingdoms were forming as the Bahmani Kingdom broke up. None of them had strong navies. The Chinese emperor limited the reach of Chinese ships, and Arab merchants had no match for the Portuguese organization and unity. The Portuguese had cannons on their ships, making them a formidable force. The Estado Português da India was a significant element in Indian history, occupying around sixty miles of coast around Goa.
summary.14: Within fifty years of Vasco da Gama's arrival, the Portuguese had control over many coastal parts of India. They occupied around sixty miles of coast around Goa and controlled a narrow tract with four important ports and hundreds of towns and villages on the west coast. In the south, they had a chain of seaport fortresses and trading-posts like Mangalore, Cannanore, Cochin, and Calicut. They also established military posts and settlements on the east coast and in West Bengal, and signed treaties with the Deccan sultans.
summary.15: The Portuguese played a role in battles for power in India. They were the first and last Europeans to come to India, leaving in 1961. The viceroy was the head of administration, with a council and Vedor da Fazenda. Fortresses were under captains and factors. The Portuguese had conflicts with Moors and Arabs.
summary.16: The Portuguese wanted to promote Christianity and persecute Muslims in the East. They were initially tolerant towards Hindus, but later persecuted them too. However, the Jesuits made a good impression at the court of Akbar, who was interested in theology. Akbar invited two priests from Goa to convert him and his court to Christianity. Jesuit fathers, Rodolfo Aquaviva and Antonio Monserrate, were selected for the purpose.
summary.17: The Jesuits were invited by Akbar to convert him and his court to Christianity. Aquaviva and Monserrate were selected for the purpose and were received with honour when they reached Fatehpur Sikri. However, their mission failed and the hopes of the Portuguese were belying. The third mission arrived in 1595 and became a sort of permanent institution, extending its influence on secular politics.
summary.18: The Jesuits were allowed to keep the church and priests' residence in Lahore. In 1608, the priests baptized people in Agra and hoped to convert Jahangir to Christianity, but their hopes were dashed. The Portuguese viceroys' arrogance caused a rift with the Mughal emperor. Captain William Hawkins arrived in Surat with a letter from King James I, requesting permission to do business in India. Despite the Portuguese authorities' efforts to stop him, Hawkins met with Jahangir and conversed with him in Turki.
summary.19: Hawkins spoke Turki with Jahangir and was appointed as a mansabdar of 400 with a salary of Rs 30,000. He married Mubarikesha, daughter of an Armenian Christian. The Portuguese were offended by the grant of trading facilities to the English, but a truce was established after negotiations. Hawkins left the Mughal court in 1611, unable to counter the Portuguese intrigues. In November 1612, the English ship Dragon successfully fought a Portuguese fleet, impressing Jahangir. The Portuguese acts of piracy resulted in conflict with the Mughal government.
summary.20:
The Portuguese piracy caused conflict with the Mughal government. In 1613, they captured Mughal ships, imprisoned Muslims, and plundered cargoes. Jahangir ordered compensation, but it was during Shah Jahan's reign that the Portuguese lost their advantages in the Mughal court. They also lost hope of converting the royal family to Christianity. 

The Portuguese settled on a river bank near Satgaon in Bengal for trading. They built big buildings and the trade moved to the new port of Hooghly.
summary.21: The Portuguese controlled salt production, built their own custom house, and enforced tobacco taxes strictly. They also engaged in a cruel slave trade, taking Hindu and Muslim children as slaves. In 1632, the Mughal siege of Hooghly began, leading to the capture of the city three months later. The Portuguese fled, and the Mughals took 400 prisoners who were given the choice to convert to Islam or become slaves. The persecution of Christians continued for some time before gradually dying down.
summary.22: By the 18th century, the Portuguese lost their commercial influence in India. Some continued trade individually, while others turned to piracy and robbery. Hooghly was used as a base for piracy in the Bay of Bengal. The decline was due to the emergence of powerful dynasties in Egypt, Persia, and North India, the rise of the Marathas, and their religious policies, trade practices, and piracy.
summary.23: The Portuguese became sea pirates and were disliked by rulers and the Mughals. Portugal's focus shifted to Brazil and they were dragged into Spain's wars. The Dutch and English learned the sea route to India, ending Portuguese trade monopoly.
summary.24: With the arrival of new European traders in India, competition grew fierce. The Portuguese, with their limited resources, were unable to compete with the more powerful Dutch and English. These new competitors had greater resources and a stronger drive to expand overseas, ultimately overcoming Portuguese resistance.
summary.25: Goa lost its importance as a port after the fall of the Vijayanagara empire. The Dutch controlled the spice trade and Brazil became the new economic center of Portugal's overseas empire. In 1683, the Marathas invaded Goa. The Portuguese marked the emergence of naval power in India and gained monopoly over trade with the use of force.
summary.26: The Portuguese ships had cannons, which helped them gain a monopoly over trade through force. They did not follow any rules and wanted to dominate the Indian Ocean trading system. They also showed military innovation on land, such as using body armour and guns, and introduced drilling groups of infantry, which was later adopted by other armies in India. The Portuguese were skilled at sea and improved techniques in naval power.
summary.27: The Portuguese ships were strong and had many decks, allowing them to carry heavy weapons. They used castles on the front and back to defend against boarding. They also had good organization, with royal arsenals and a system of pilots and mapping. The Portuguese taught the Mughals and Marathas, but the Dutch and English learned the most. The Portuguese also taught art in India.
summary.28: The Portuguese missionaries and Church were also teachers and patrons of the arts in India, including painting, carving, and sculpture. They introduced European art to India and helped the art of silversmith and goldsmith flourish in Goa. However, the churches built by the Portuguese were generally simple in their architectural plan. The Dutch also arrived in India and founded their first factory in Masulipatnam in 1605, after forming the East India Company of the Netherlands in 1602.
summary.29: After arriving in India, the Dutch established their first factory in Masulipatnam in 1605. They then set up trading centers in different parts of India, becoming a threat to the Portuguese. They captured Nagapatam and made it their main stronghold in South India. The Dutch also established factories in Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh, Bengal, and Bihar, and participated in the redistributive trade, carrying various articles and merchandise from India to the islands of the Far East.
summary.30: The English challenged the Dutch in the Eastern trade, leading to warfare. The rivalry peaked at Amboyna, where the Dutch massacred ten Englishmen and nine Japanese in 1623. After prolonged warfare, both parties agreed to a compromise in 1667. The Dutch retired from India to focus on their more profitable trade in Indonesia, monopolising the trade in black pepper and spices. The Dutch traded in silk, cotton, indigo, rice, and opium in India, but got drawn into the trade of the Malay Archipelago, leading to their decline in India.
summary.31: The Dutch shifted their focus to the Malay Archipelago, leading to their decline in India. In the third Anglo-Dutch War, communication between Surat and Bombay was cut, resulting in the capture of English ships by the Dutch in the Bay of Bengal.
summary.32: The English defeated the Dutch in the Battle of Hooghly in November 1759, which ended Dutch ambitions in India. The Dutch were more interested in trade than empire building in India, and their main focus was on the Spice Islands of Indonesia. The English were encouraged to venture out to the East after Francis Drake's voyage and the English victory over the Spanish Armada. In 1600, Queen Elizabeth I issued a charter to the 'Governor and Company of Merchants of London trading into the East Indies' for exclusive trading rights.
summary.33: Initially, the English East India Company had a monopoly of 15 years, which was extended indefinitely in May 1609. As the Dutch focused on the East Indies, the English turned to India for textiles and other trade commodities. Captain Hawkins arrived in India in 1609, but the attempt to establish a factory at Surat failed due to Portuguese opposition. The English began trading at Masulipatnam in 1611 and established a factory there in 1616. In 1612, Captain Thomas Best defeated the Portuguese in the sea off Surat, and Jahangir allowed the English to establish a factory at Surat in early 1613.
summary.34: In 1615, Sir Thomas Roe came to the court of Jahangir as an ambassador of James I. He secured permission to set up factories at Agra, Ahmedabad, and Broach. The English company faced competition from the Portuguese and the Dutch, but the situation changed in their favor. Bombay was gifted to King Charles II by the King of Portugal and later given to the East India Company in 1668. Bombay became the headquarters in 1687, and there was peace between the English and the Portuguese.
summary.35: The Dutch agreed not to interfere with the English company's trade in India, improving their position. The English received the 'Golden Farman' from the Sultan of Golconda in 1632, allowing them to trade freely in Golconda's ports. They built a fortified factory at Madras in 1639 and extended their trading activities to Hariharpur and Balasore. They also gained a foothold in Bengal, a large and prosperous province in India.
summary.36: The English merchants were interested in controlling Bengal for trade and profit. The subahdar of Bengal, Shah Shuja, allowed them to trade in Bengal for an annual payment of Rs 3,000. The English started factories in Hooghly, Kasimbazar, Patna, and Rajmahal. However, customs officers sometimes obstructed their business. The English wanted a fortified settlement at Hooghly for protection, but their appeal to the Mughal governor was unsuccessful, leading to hostilities.
summary.37: Hostilities broke out between the English and the Mughals after an appeal for redressal of grievances was unsuccessful. The Mughals sacked Hooghly in 1686, and the English retaliated by capturing imperial forts. However, they were forced to leave Hooghly and negotiate with the Mughals to establish a factory at Sutanuti in 1691.
summary.38: A zamindar named Sobha Singh rebelled, giving the English a reason to fortify their settlement at Sutanuti in 1696. In 1698, they bought the zamindari of Sutanuti, Gobindapur, and Kalikata for Rs 1,200. The fortified settlement was named Fort William in 1700 and became the seat of the eastern presidency with Sir Charles Eyre as its first president. In 1715, the Company secured three farmans from the Mughal emperor Farrukhsiyar, giving them many valuable privileges in Bengal, Gujarat, and Hyderabad.
summary.39: The English East India Company gained trading concessions in Bengal through flattery and diplomacy. They were allowed to issue passes for goods transportation and rent more lands around Calcutta. In Hyderabad, they were exempted from duties in trade and had to pay rent only for Madras. In Surat, they paid an annual fee of 10,000 rupees to be exempted from all duties. The coins minted by the Company in Bombay were decreed to have currency throughout the Mughal empire. The Company established a permanent factory in Surat in 1613.
summary.40: In 1613, the East India Company established a permanent factory in Surat. Two years later, Sir Thomas Roe arrived at Jahangir's court and obtained two farmans confirming free trade with exemption from inland tolls. The Company also established its first factories in Masulipatnam and Hariharpur, Balasore, and obtained the golden farman from the Sultan of Golconda. In 1639, the Company got the lease of Madras and in 1651, permission to trade at Hooghly. In 1662, Charles II was given Bombay as dowry and in 1667, Aurangzeb gave the English a farman for trade in Bengal. In 1691, the Company got the imperial order to continue their trade in Bengal.
summary.41: In 1717, the Mughal emperor Farrukhsiyar gave the East India Company many trade concessions through a farman called Magna Carta of the Company. This helped the Company to become more powerful and gain control over India. After the English revolution of 1688, a rival company was formed, but it failed. In 1708, the two companies were merged to form the East India Company, which ruled India from 1708 to 1873.
summary.42: The French established the Compagnie des Indes Orientales in 1664, with a 50-year monopoly on trade in the Indian and Pacific Oceans. The company was granted a concession in perpetuity for Madagascar and any other territories it could conquer. Francois Caron set up a factory in Surat in 1667 and Mercara founded another in Masulipatnam in 1669.
summary.43: Mercara founded a French factory in Masulipatnam in 1669 with a patent from the Sultan of Golconda. In 1673, the French obtained permission from Shaista Khan to establish a township at Chandernagore near Calcutta. Pondicherry was founded in 1674 and became the stronghold of the French in India. The French also established factories in other coastal regions.
summary.44: Pondicherry was the stronghold of the French in India. However, the outbreak of war between the Dutch and the French badly affected the French position in India. The Dutch captured Pondicherry in 1693, but it was restored to the French in 1697. The War of Spanish Succession caused the French to abandon their factories in Surat, Masulipatnam, and Bantam. Francois Martin's death in 1706 was another setback. The French company was reorganised as the 'Perpetual Company of the Indies' in 1720, which revived its strength.
summary.45: The French company regained strength under Lenoir and Dumas, who were wise governors from 1720 to 1742. French India was supported by the French possession of Mauritius and Reunion in the southern Indian Ocean. The Anglo-French Struggle for Supremacy: the Carnatic Wars began with the outbreak of the Austrian War of Succession and ended with the conclusion of the Seven Years’ War.
summary.46: In 1740, the political situation in south India was uncertain. The Nizam Asaf Jah of Hyderabad was old and busy fighting the Marathas, while his subordinates were unsure of what would happen after his death. The Coromandel Coast had no strong ruler, and there were small states in the east. The decline of Hyderabad marked the end of Muslim expansionism, and the English were ready to take advantage. The Maratha kingdom of Tanjore also provided an excuse for interference. This led to the First Carnatic War (1740-48), fought over control of the Coromandel Coast.
summary.47: The First Carnatic War was caused by the Anglo-French War in Europe. The English provoked France by seizing their ships, leading to France taking Madras in 1746. The war ended in 1748 with the Treaty of Aix-La Chapelle, returning Madras to the English. The Battle of St. Thome was a significant event in the war.
summary.48: During the First Carnatic War, a small French army led by Captain Paradise defeated a larger Indian army at St. Thome, revealing the effectiveness of disciplined European armies. The importance of naval force in the Anglo-French conflict was also highlighted. The Second Carnatic War (1749-54) was caused by French governor Dupleix's desire to increase French influence in southern India by interfering in local disputes, which was made possible by the death of Nizam-ul-Mulk and the release of Chanda Sahib by the Marathas.
summary.49: After the death of Nizam-ul-Mulk, a dispute arose between his son Nasir Jung and grandson Muzaffar Jung over the throne of Hyderabad. In the Carnatic, Anwaruddin Khan was appointed Nawab, but Chanda Sahib opposed it. The French supported Muzaffar Jung and Chanda Sahib, while the English supported Nasir Jung and Anwaruddin. The combined forces of Muzaffar Jung, Chanda Sahib, and the French defeated Anwaruddin at the Battle of Ambur in 1749. Muzaffar Jung became the subahdar of Deccan, and Dupleix was appointed governor of all Mughal territories south of the River Krishna. A French army under Bussy was stationed at Hyderabad to secure French interests.
summary.50: To secure their interests, the French stationed an army under Bussy in Hyderabad and were ceded territories near Pondicherry and Masulipatnam. Robert Clive proposed a diversionary attack on Madras governor Saunders by capturing Arcot, the capital of the Carnatic. Chanda Sahib failed to recapture the fort after a 53-day siege, and Trichinopoly was relieved with the aid of Mysore, Tanjore, and Maratha chief Morari Rao. General Law of France and Chanda Sahib remained cooped up in Srirangam.
summary.51: Trichinopoly was relieved of its siege with the help of Mysore, Tanjore, and Maratha chief Morari Rao. General Law of France and Chanda Sahib surrendered in June 1752 after Muhammad Ali executed Chanda Sahib, with no interference from the British.
summary.52: Dupleix was appointed as the Director-General of French colonies in India and later conferred the title of Nawab. He was known for his administrative, diplomatic, and leadership qualities. As the Governor-General of Pondicherry, he faced several challenges such as Maratha invasion, famine, and chaotic conditions in the Carnatic. Despite opposition, he reduced public expenditure and balanced income and expenditure. He also enhanced the defences of Pondicherry and made it the emporium of commerce in south India.
summary.53: Dupleix made Pondicherry a hub of trade in south India by developing its commerce. Despite opposition, he fortified the settlement and balanced income and expenditure. The Directors praised him for his decisions. Dupleix used diplomacy to protect French settlements and defeat the English. He promised the nawab Madras but did not give it to him, and convinced Admiral La Bourdonnais to break promises made to the English.
summary.54: Dupleix convinced his subordinate to break promises made to the English, citing historical examples. He interfered in Indian politics, supporting Muzzaffar Jang and Chanda Sahib, and originated the practice of subsidiary alliance. However, he was recalled in 1754 due to the initial defeat of the French army and the cost incurred by the company. Historians consider it a blunder, resulting from a compromise between France and England over issues in America.
summary.55: Many historians believe that Dupleix's recall was a mistake due to a compromise between France and England over issues in America. However, Dupleix had weaknesses, including his over-sanguine temperament, autocratic behavior, and lack of action. The French failed to capture Trichinopoly because Dupleix's plans could not be executed. The French authorities recalled him in 1754 due to heavy financial losses. Godeheu succeeded him and adopted a policy of negotiations with the English, concluding a treaty with them.

story.0:
Long ago, there was a time when India was ruled by different people. It is hard to say when one period ended and another began. But, if we start with the arrival of the Europeans, we have to go back to the 15th century. Even before the Mughals came to power. 

At that time, the Arabs controlled the trade routes to India. The Europeans found it hard to get Indian goods like spices, silk, and precious stones. But, in 1453, the Ottoman Turks took over Constantinople. This made it even harder for the Europeans to trade with India.
story.1: Long ago, the Ottomans took over Constantinople and controlled the trade routes to India. The Europeans had to rely on Arab Muslim traders to get Indian goods, but they wanted a direct sea route. They built better ships and explored the unknown corners of the East. They also needed spices for cooking and preservation, and the demand for luxury goods grew with prosperity.
story.2: As Europe prospered, so did the desire for exotic goods from the East. Venice and Genoa were too small to compete with the Ottoman Turks, but the north Europeans were eager to help Portugal and Spain. Portugal led the way in resisting Islam and exploring new lands, with Prince Henry the Navigator obsessed with finding a sea route to India and bypassing Muslim control.
story.3: Long ago, Prince Henry of Portugal had a dream to find a new way to reach India. He wanted to trade with the people there and spread the Christian faith. The Pope gave him permission to sail across the sea to India, but Prince Henry died before he could make the journey. Later, Portugal and Spain divided the world between them, and Portugal set out to find the sea route to India. A brave navigator named Bartholomew Dias sailed around the southern tip of Africa and believed he had found the way. Ten years later, a group of Portuguese ships set sail for India and arrived there in less than a year.
story.4: Long ago, a prince named Henry dreamed of sailing to far-off lands to spread his faith. But he passed away before he could make it happen. Later, two countries divided the world between them, with Portugal claiming the east and Spain the west. A Portuguese navigator named Bartholomew Dias found a sea route to India, and ten years later, Vasco Da Gama arrived in India with three ships. The Hindu ruler welcomed him, but Arab traders were worried about the Portuguese taking over the trading system in the Indian Ocean.
story.5: The Portuguese wanted to control the eastern trade and make lots of money. Vasco da Gama stayed in India for three months and sold his cargo for a big profit in Europe. Other Europeans wanted to come to India and trade too. Pedro Alvarez Cabral came to Calicut and set up a factory, but there was a fight and some Portuguese died.
story.6: After Vasco da Gama's successful trip to India, the Portuguese wanted to control the trade and exclude the Arabs. Pedro Alvarez Cabral arrived in Calicut to trade for spices, but there was conflict and he attacked Arab ships. Later, he made treaties with local rulers. Vasco da Gama returned, but the Zamorin refused to exclude the Arabs. Vasco da Gama became hostile and attacked Arab shipping. This marked a new era in world history.
story.7: The Portuguese wanted to find a new way to India to hurt their enemies, the Muslims, Arabs, and Turks. They wanted to take over the trade in spices and find a Christian ruler called Prester John. They hoped to attack the Muslims from two sides and become very powerful.
story.8: The Portuguese wanted to find a new way to reach India and take control of the spice trade. They also wanted to defeat their enemies, the Muslims, Arabs, and Turks. They hoped to find a Christian ruler named Prester John and attack the Muslims from two sides. Vasco da Gama set up a trading factory in Cannanore and the Portuguese gradually became powerful. They built fortresses to protect their trade and appointed a governor, Francisco De Almeida, to destroy Muslim trade and build more fortresses. He said that being powerful at sea was more important than having fortresses on land.
story.9:
When Francisco De Almeida became the governor of India, he wanted to make the Portuguese the rulers of the Indian Ocean. He built fortresses in Cannanore, Kilwa, and other places to protect their trading activities. But he faced a threat from the Mameluke Sultan of Egypt, who wanted to stop the Portuguese. In a naval battle off Diu, Almeida's son was killed, but the next year, Almeida avenged his defeat and crushed the two navies. Almeida's vision was known as the Blue Water Policy. 

After Almeida, Alfonso de Albuquerque became the governor of India. He wanted to make Portugal the most powerful country in the East. He established bases overlooking all the entrances to the sea, securing strategic control of the Indian Ocean. Albuquerque completed this task before his death and became the real founder of Portuguese power in the East.
story.10: Albuquerque, a Portuguese governor, wanted to make his country the master of the Indian Ocean. He built strongholds in East Africa, Malabar, and Malacca. He controlled ship-building centers and introduced a permit system for other ships. He even acquired Goa from the Sultan of Bijapur in 1510. However, his policy of persecuting Muslims was a drawback.
story.11: Albuquerque wanted to help his countrymen by getting rid of Muslim businesses in the East. He made Goa stronger and more important for trade. He also told his men to marry Indian women so they could stay in India forever. The Portuguese men became landlords, built new things, and grew new crops. They loved their new home in India.
story.12: When Nino da Cunha became governor of Portuguese interests in India, he moved the government headquarters to Goa. Bahadur Shah of Gujarat gave the Portuguese the island of Bassein and promised them a base in Diu. But when Humayun left Gujarat, the people of the town fought with the Portuguese. The ruler of Gujarat was invited to a Portuguese ship and killed in 1537.
story.13:
In the Deccan, there were many small kingdoms. None of them had strong ships, and they didn't try to make their navy better. The Chinese emperor said his ships couldn't go far. Arab merchants and ship-owners couldn't match the Portuguese. The Portuguese had cannons on their ships. 

The Portuguese State was important in Indian history. They controlled many coastal parts of India within fifty years of Vasco da Gama's arrival. They had taken over about sixty miles of coast around Goa.
story.14: Long ago, the Portuguese arrived in India led by Vasco da Gama. They quickly gained control of many coastal areas, including a sixty-mile stretch around Goa. They had four important ports and many towns and villages under their control. They also had a chain of seaport fortresses and trading-posts in the south. The Portuguese even established military posts and settlements on the east coast and in West Bengal. They made treaties with the Deccan sultans and exchanged envoys with many kingdoms in India.
story.15: Long ago, the Portuguese came to India and took control of many coastal areas. They had important ports and trading-posts, and even had influence over local rulers. They also established settlements on the east coast. The Portuguese were involved in many battles for power in India and were the last Europeans to leave. The head of their administration was the viceroy, and they had a religious policy that made enemies of the Moors and Arabs. In 1961, the Government of India recaptured Goa, Daman and Diu from them.
story.16: Long ago, the Portuguese came to the East with a strong desire to spread Christianity. They did not like the Muslims, who were their enemies in North Africa. At first, they were kind to the Hindus, but later they became cruel to them too. However, the Jesuits made a good impression on the Mughal emperor Akbar, who was interested in theology. He invited two priests to his court, hoping to learn more about Christianity. The Jesuits were happy to go and spread their faith.
story.17: When the Jesuit fathers Aquaviva and Monserrate arrived in Fatehpur Sikri, they were welcomed with respect. But their hope of converting Emperor Akbar to Christianity was not fulfilled. Two more missions were sent, but they too failed. The third mission, led by Fathers Xavier and Pinheiro, stayed in Lahore and became influential in politics. Jahangir, who became the new emperor, initially ignored the Jesuits but later allowed them to keep their church and residence.
story.18: The Jesuit priests were allowed to keep their church in Lahore and even baptized people in Agra. They hoped to convert Jahangir to Christianity, but it didn't happen. The Portuguese also caused problems with the Mughal emperor. Captain Hawkins from England was able to meet Jahangir and do business with him, despite the Portuguese's efforts to stop him.
story.19: Hawkins spoke the Turki language and talked with Jahangir without an interpreter. Jahangir liked him and made him a mansabdar of 400 with a salary of Rs 30,000. Hawkins married Mubarikesha, an Armenian Christian's daughter. The Portuguese were angry with the English trading facilities, but they made peace with the Mughal emperor. Hawkins left in 1611, but in 1612, Captain Best fought and won against the Portuguese. Jahangir was impressed, and the Portuguese piracy caused problems with the Mughal government.
story.20: The Portuguese were causing trouble by stealing from Mughal ships and hurting Muslims. Jahangir was angry and ordered compensation. But it was Shah Jahan who finally stopped the Portuguese from having too much power in the Mughal court. The Portuguese had hoped to convert the royal family to Christianity, but that dream was lost. Meanwhile, the Portuguese had built big buildings in Hooghly and moved their trade there.
story.21: Long ago, the Portuguese came to a land called Mughal India. They traded and made money, but they also did bad things. They took Hindu and Muslim children and made them Christians. They even took two girls from a very important family. The Mughal leader, Shah Jahan, was very angry and ordered his soldiers to capture the Portuguese city of Hooghly. After three months, they succeeded and the Portuguese had to leave. Some soldiers were taken as prisoners and given a choice to become Muslim or slaves. The bad things the Portuguese did to the people of Mughal India stopped after this.
story.22: Long ago, the Portuguese came to India and became very rich by trading salt and tobacco. But they also did bad things, like taking Hindu and Muslim children as slaves. They even took two girls from Mumtaz Mahal! The Mughal emperor, Shah Jahan, was angry and attacked the Portuguese in Hooghly. After a long fight, the Portuguese had to leave. Later, they lost their power because other countries became stronger and people didn't like their bad behavior.
story.23: Long ago, the Portuguese came to India with swords and crosses. They found gold and forgot about the crosses, filling their pockets instead. They became pirates and made enemies with rulers and the Mughals. They also tried to convert Hindus to Christianity, which made them angry. The Dutch and English learned the sea route to India, ending Portuguese trade monopoly. Portugal also got involved in Spain's wars and discovered Brazil, so they left India.
story.24: The Portuguese were once sea pirates who were known for their arrogance and violence. They came to India with a sword in one hand and a crucifix in the other, but soon forgot about the crucifix when they found gold. However, their monopoly of trade in India was challenged by the Dutch and the English, who were also learning the skills of ocean navigation. These new competitors had greater resources and overcame the Portuguese resistance, leading to a fierce rivalry among them. In the end, the Portuguese had to give way to the more powerful and enterprising competitors.
story.25: Long ago, when new traders from Europe came to India, they fought fiercely for power. The Portuguese were strong, but the Dutch and English were even stronger. They took over the spice trade and Goa lost its importance. The Marathas invaded Goa in 1683. The Portuguese were the first foreign power to come to India by sea, and they used their ships and cannons to gain control of trade.
story.26: Long ago, a foreign power arrived in India by way of the sea. They were called the Portuguese and their ships carried powerful weapons called cannon. The Portuguese wanted to control trade and declared they would follow their own rules. They used their weapons to gain an advantage over the Indians and the Indian Ocean trading system. The Portuguese also showed military innovation on land, teaching others how to drill infantry and use guns. They were masters of improved techniques at sea.
story.27: The Portuguese ships were strong and had many levels, with big guns to protect them. They had special parts at the front and back to stop enemies from getting on board. The Indians copied these ideas. The Portuguese were also good at planning and had special places to make and fix their ships. They taught other Europeans how to do this too. The Portuguese also helped Indian artists, but some people remember them for being mean to different religions.
story.28: The Portuguese were great sailors who built strong ships to withstand storms. They also had powerful weapons to protect themselves from enemies. They taught Indians how to make beautiful art and music. The Dutch were also good sailors and formed a company to trade and fight wars. They built their first factory in Masulipatnam.
story.29: Long ago, the Dutch sailed to India and built their first factory in Masulipatnam. They made many trading centers and became a threat to the Portuguese. They captured Nagapatam and made it their main stronghold in South India. They built factories in many places like Surat, Bengal, and Bihar. They traded many things like indigo, textiles, and opium.
story.30: Long ago, the Dutch came to India and set up trading centres in many places. They became a threat to the Portuguese and even captured their stronghold in South India. They traded many things like indigo, textiles, and rice. But then, the English also came to trade in the East and this made the Dutch very angry. They even had a big fight in a place called Amboyna. After many years of fighting, they made a deal. The British left Indonesia and the Dutch left India to focus on trading spices in Indonesia. The Dutch slowly stopped trading in India and started trading in the Malay Archipelago instead.
story.31: The Dutch were once powerful in India, but they became greedy and wanted more. They went to the Malay Archipelago to trade, but this made them weak. They fought with the English and captured their ships. But, in the end, they lost their power and had to leave India.
story.32: The Dutch and English were rivals in India. The Dutch wanted to trade and colonize the East Indies, while the English wanted a share of the profits. In a battle, the English defeated the Dutch, crushing their ambitions in India. The Dutch were more interested in trading spices from Indonesia, where they made a lot of money. The English formed a company to trade in the East Indies, with exclusive rights granted by Queen Elizabeth I.
story.33: Long ago, the Dutch were not interested in ruling India, but they loved to trade. They made a lot of money from the Spice Islands in Indonesia. The English saw this and wanted to join in. They formed a company called the 'Governor and Company of Merchants of London trading into the East Indies' in 1600. They were given a monopoly for 15 years, which was extended indefinitely in 1609. They tried to set up a factory in Surat, but the Portuguese stopped them. They succeeded in Masulipatnam in 1611 and Surat in 1613.
story.34: Sir Thomas Roe went to meet Jahangir, the Mughal emperor, in 1615. He stayed there for four years but couldn't make a trade deal. However, he got permission to set up factories in Agra, Ahmedabad, and Broach. The English company had a tough time with the Portuguese and Dutch, but things changed. Bombay was gifted to King Charles II, and later, the East India Company got it for a small fee. Bombay became the headquarters in 1687, and there was peace between the English and Portuguese.
story.35: Long ago, the English company faced many challenges in India. They had to compete with the Portuguese and the Dutch for trade. But things changed when Bombay was gifted to King Charles II and later given to the English company. They also received a special permission to trade in Golconda and built a fortified factory in Madras. They even started trading in Bengal, a rich province in India. With the help of these privileges, the English company became successful in India.
story.36: The English merchants wanted to control Bengal's trade and politics. The governor, Shah Shuja, agreed to let them trade for Rs 3,000 a year. They started factories in Hooghly, Kasimbazar, Patna, and Rajmahal. But sometimes, customs officers asked for tolls. The English wanted a fortified settlement in Hooghly, but the Mughal governor, Shaista Khan, didn't help. So, the English and Mughals fought.
story.37: After the English appealed for help, the Mughals refused to listen. This led to a fight between the two groups. Four years later, the Mughals attacked and destroyed Hooghly. The English fought back by capturing Mughal forts and raiding their territories. However, they were forced to leave Hooghly and move to an unhealthy location. Later, they negotiated with the Mughals and returned to Sutanuti, where they established a factory and paid Rs 3,000 a year. A zamindar's rebellion gave them the chance to fortify their settlement in 1696.
story.38:
After returning to Sutanuti, the English faced rebellion from a zamindar named Sobha Singh. This gave them the chance to fortify their settlement in 1696. Two years later, they bought the zamindari of Sutanuti, Gobindapur, and Kalikata for Rs 1,200. The fortified settlement was named Fort William in 1700 and became the seat of the eastern presidency with Sir Charles Eyre as its first president.

In 1715, John Surman led an English mission to the court of Mughal emperor Farrukhsiyar. They secured three farmans that gave the Company many valuable privileges in Bengal, Gujarat, and Hyderabad. The farmans exempted the Company's imports and exports from additional customs duties, allowed them to issue passes for transportation of goods, and permitted them to rent more lands around Calcutta. These farmans were regarded as the Magna Carta of the Company.
story.39:
Long ago, the English East India Company came to India to trade. They were allowed to transport goods with special passes called dastaks. They were also allowed to rent more land around Calcutta. In Hyderabad, they didn't have to pay trade duties and only had to pay rent for Madras. In Surat, they paid 10,000 rupees each year to be exempt from all duties. The coins they made in Bombay were accepted all over the Mughal empire.

The English were very clever and used flattery and diplomacy to get these trading concessions from the Mughal authority. But they had to defeat the French first. The East India Company was established in 1600 and in 1609, William Hawkins arrived at Jahangir's court. Captain Middleton got permission to trade in Surat in 1611 and in 1613, the East India Company set up a permanent factory there.
story.40: In 1613, the East India Company made a permanent factory in Surat. Two years later, Sir Thomas Roe, the ambassador of King James I, arrived at Jahangir's court and got two farmans for free trade. The Company also established factories in Masulipatnam, Hariharpur, and Madras. They got permission to trade in Hooghly and Bengal, and even got Bombay as dowry. The Company continued their trade in Bengal by paying Rs 3,000 a year.
story.41:
Once upon a time, a powerful emperor named Farrukhsiyar issued a special paper called Magna Carta for the Company. This paper gave the Company many trade benefits. The Company was very happy because they could now control all the trade in India and become very rich.

But, there was another group of English people who did not like the Company having all the power. They formed a new company and sent Sir William Norris to talk to the emperor. However, this new company did not do well. So, the two companies joined together in 1708 to become the East India Company. This Company became very powerful and ruled India for many years.
story.42: Long ago, the French wanted to trade in the East, but they were the last Europeans to come to India. King Louis XIV helped create the Compagnie des Indes Orientales in 1664, which had a 50-year monopoly on French trade in the Indian and Pacific Oceans. The Company tried to revive colonies in Madagascar, but failed. In 1667, Francois Caron set up a factory in Surat and Mercara founded another in Masulipatnam in 1669.
story.43: Long ago, the French wanted to trade with the East, but they were the last to arrive in India. They started a company called Compagnie des Indes Orientales and tried to conquer Madagascar, but it didn't work. In 1667, Francois Caron went to India and set up a factory in Surat. Mercara, a Persian, started another factory in Masulipatnam in 1669. Later, the French established a township at Chandernagore and founded Pondicherry in 1674. Francois Martin became the governor and developed it as a place of importance.
story.44: Long ago, the French came to India and built a strong place called Pondicherry. But they faced troubles when the Dutch attacked and took over. After many years, the French got Pondicherry back and it became even stronger. But then, a big war in Europe made them leave some of their other places in India. When their leader Francois Martin died, they were sad. But later, they reorganised and became strong again.
story.45:
In the land of India, the French had a strong fort called Pondicherry. But they faced many challenges, like when the Dutch took over the fort. However, a wise leader named Francois Martin helped the French regain control. Later, the French company was reorganized and became strong again with the help of two governors named Lenoir and Dumas. They also had support from the French colonies in Mauritius and Reunion. 

The British and French both came to India for trade, but they wanted power too. They fought many wars, called the Carnatic wars, to decide who would rule India. The English won and became the masters of India. This rivalry started with the Austrian War of Succession and ended with the Seven Years’ War. In 1740, the situation in south India was confusing.
story.46: In south India, the situation was uncertain and confusing in 1740. The old ruler of Hyderabad was busy fighting the Marathas, and his subordinates were worried about what would happen when he died. There were small states in the east and remnants of the old Vijayanagara empire in the interior. The English saw an opportunity when Hyderabad declined, and the Marathas interfered whenever they pleased. This led to the first Carnatic War (1740-48) over control of the Coromandel Coast.
story.47: Long ago, there was a land called Carnatic, ruled by many small kingdoms. The Europeans came to India and fought a big war in their own land. The English wanted to fight in India too, so they took some French ships. The French got angry and took over Madras with the help of their navy. This started the first Carnatic War. The war ended when a treaty was signed, giving Madras back to the English. The war is remembered for the Battle of St. Thome.
story.48:
Long ago, there was a battle at St. Thome between the French and Indian armies. Captain Paradise led a small French army to victory over the strong Indian army under Mahfuz Khan. This showed the Europeans that even a small, disciplined army could defeat a much larger Indian army. The importance of naval force in the Anglo-French conflict in the Deccan was also revealed. 

Later, there was another war called the Second Carnatic War. The French governor, Dupleix, wanted to increase his power and French political influence in southern India by interfering in local dynastic disputes to defeat the English. When Nizam-ul-Mulk, the founder of the independent kingdom of Hyderabad, died in 1748, and Chanda Sahib, the son-in-law of Dost Ali, the Nawab of Carnatic, was released by the Marathas, the opportunity for war arose.
story.49: In the land of India, there was a great rivalry between the French and the English. The French governor, Dupleix, wanted to increase his power and influence by interfering in local disputes. When the founder of Hyderabad died, Dupleix saw an opportunity to support Muzaffar Jang's claim to the throne against Nasir Jung. In the Carnatic, the French supported Chanda Sahib against Anwaruddin Khan. The French and their allies won the Battle of Ambur, and Muzaffar Jang became the subahdar of Deccan. Dupleix was appointed governor of all the Mughal territories to the south of the River Krishna, and a French army was stationed at Hyderabad to secure their interests.
story.50: The French army was sent to Hyderabad to protect their interests. The French were given some territories near Pondicherry and Masulipatnam. Robert Clive suggested attacking Arcot to divert Chanda Sahib's attention from Trichinopoly. With only 210 men, Clive captured Arcot. Chanda Sahib failed to recapture the fort even after a 53-day siege. Mysore, Tanjore, and Morari Rao helped Clive and Stringer Lawrence. Trichinopoly was relieved, while Chanda Sahib was trapped on the island of Srirangam.
story.51: After the victory at Arcot, Trichinopoly was saved from siege. General Law and Chanda Sahib were trapped on an island and surrendered when Muhammad Ali executed Chanda Sahib. Meanwhile, Joseph Francis Dupleix, a wealthy man, became governor of Chandernagore and Director-General of French colonies in India. He even became a Nawab.
story.52: Dupleix was a clever man with many talents. He became the Governor of Pondicherry and faced many problems, like famine and chaos. He reduced spending and balanced the budget, but he also disobeyed the directors and spent his own money to make Pondicherry stronger. He even made it a great place for trade. The Mughal emperor and subahdar of Deccan, Muzzaffar Jang, were so impressed that they gave him the title of Nawab.
story.53: Dupleix was a great leader who made Pondicherry a hub of trade in south India. He worked hard to develop the colony's commerce and even spent his own money to make it stronger. The Directors of the Company were happy with his decisions, even when they disagreed. Dupleix was also a master of diplomacy. He used the Nawab of Carnatic to protect Pondicherry from the English and promised him Madras in return. But Dupleix was clever and didn't give Madras to the nawab. He even defeated him in battle and convinced Admiral La Bourdonnais to break promises made to the English.
story.54: Dupleix was a wise leader who knew how to make his colony prosper. He made Pondicherry a great place for trade and commerce. He even convinced the Nawab of Carnatic to help protect the French settlements. Dupleix was very clever and used his diplomacy to make sure the French were successful. He even supported certain Indian rulers and created a new way of forming alliances. Sadly, Dupleix was eventually recalled because of the cost of his decisions. Some people think this was a mistake, but it was really because of issues between France and England.
story.55: Dupleix was a clever man who interfered in Indian politics. He helped Muzzaffar Jang and Chanda Sahib become rulers and they gave him many gifts. Dupleix even made a new kind of alliance called a "subsidy alliance". But he was too hopeful and his friends didn't like his bossy ways. He never fought in battles and his plans didn't work. The French lost money and recalled him in 1754. A new governor named Godeheu made peace with the English.
story.56: Godeheu became the new French governor in India after Dupleix. He talked with the English and they made a promise not to interfere in each other's affairs. This was a peaceful solution to the struggle between France and England for power in India.
story.57:
Long ago, two powerful kingdoms, England and France, fought for control of a faraway land called India. A man named Dupleix led the French, while a man named Clive led the English. They fought many battles, but eventually the English won. The French and English made a treaty, promising not to interfere in the quarrels of the Indian princes. The French kept the land they already had, and the English kept theirs. The Indians realized they needed the help of the Europeans to succeed. The French and English continued to fight in other parts of the world, but their war in India was over. 

Later, when Austria wanted to recover a land called Silesia, a big war called the Seven Years' War started. The French and English were on opposite sides again. In India, the French captured two English forts, but the English fought back and won. The war lasted for many years, but eventually the English became the most powerful in India.
story.58: After capturing English forts, the French were defeated by the English at Wandiwash. General Eyre Coote led the English army to victory and took Count Thomas Arthur de Lally as prisoner. The French power in India decreased and Lally was executed. The Treaty of Peace of Paris restored French factories, but their political influence vanished.
story.59: After defeating the French at Wandiwash, the English became the most powerful European force in India. The French, Portuguese, and Dutch stayed in their small areas and focused on trade. The English received support from Bengal and had a constant supply of food and money, while the French struggled to get supplies. This victory was a turning point in British rule over India.
story.60: Long ago, Europeans came to India to trade and rule. The English became the strongest, defeating the Dutch and French. They won a big battle at Wandiwash, leaving no rivals. The English had food, money, and men, while the French had nothing. This made the English stronger and the French weaker. Coote won against Lally and trapped him in Pondicherry. The natives fought on both sides, but India fell to the Europeans because of native rulers' lack of foresight. The English company was private and confident, while the French company was controlled by the government.
story.61: In a far-off land, two companies came to conquer. The French company was controlled by the government, which made it slow to make decisions. The English company was free to act quickly, which gave them an advantage. The English navy was strong and cut off the French from their home country. The English had three important places, while the French only had one. The French cared more about land than money, which left them short of funds. The English were smart and always kept their commercial interests in mind. They had great leaders who helped them win.
story.62: Long ago, people loved colorful fabrics like painted cloths, silks, and dyes. Indians had been trading these textiles for many years. Even in faraway places like China and Japan, people loved Indian cotton for its lightness and strength. When the Dutch, English, and French got these fabrics from India, they didn't just keep them for themselves. They traded them for spices in places like Malacca and Java.
story.63: In the 18th century, the French made special handkerchiefs with colorful patterns for different islands. This was a smart business move. But, there was a dark side to the textile and spice trade. Slavery was a part of it. French ships went to Asia to get cowry shells and Indian textiles. They traded these for slaves in Africa, who were then sent to the French colonies in the Americas. The circle was complete when goods from the Americas were sent back to France. The French East India Company was part of a complex economic system in India.
story.64: In India, many merchants worked together to run big businesses. They made things like cloth and spices and sold them to other countries. The European traders had to learn how to work with the Indian merchants and follow their rules. At first, there was enough for everyone, but as more companies came, the English became the most successful. They knew how to work with the Indians and grew bigger and bigger.
story.65: Long ago, Indian merchants ran big fleets and businesses with the help of weavers and brokers. European traders had to learn the rules and work with locals to succeed. The English were the best at this and expanded their factories to bigger towns. They became so powerful that they controlled all of India. The Danes also came, but they were not successful and sold their factories to the British. The English succeeded because they knew how to work with the locals and other traders.
story.66: Long ago, many traders from Europe came to India to trade. The English formed a big company, controlled by a board of directors elected every year. Shareholders had a lot of power, as they could buy and sell votes. The French and Portuguese companies were owned by the State, and the monarch had a big share. Shareholders didn't care much about the company's success, as the State promised them money. The English company became the most powerful and successful.
story.67: In the land of trading companies, there were three different types. The English East India Company was controlled by a board of directors elected every year. The French and Portuguese companies were owned by the State and had little interest in promoting prosperity. The British had the strongest navy, which helped them defeat their enemies in India. They also started the Industrial Revolution with new machines that improved production.
story.68:
Long ago, England was a powerful nation. They had the biggest and most advanced navy in Europe, which helped them win battles against other countries. They also had new machines that made things like clothes and metal faster and better than anyone else. This made England very rich and powerful, and other countries couldn't catch up because they were too slow to start using these machines. 

England also had very good soldiers who were well-trained and disciplined. Their commanders were very smart and came up with new ways to fight in battles. They also had good weapons and technology that helped them win even when they were outnumbered. England also had a stable government with good leaders, which helped them stay strong while other countries were having problems. This is how England became so powerful and stayed that way for a long time.
story.69:
Long ago, there were many powerful countries in Europe. They had big armies and wanted to control other lands. One country, called Britain, was very good at fighting. Their soldiers were well-trained and their commanders were smart. They also had new machines that helped them make things faster. 

Britain was also lucky because they had stable leaders who were good at ruling. They didn't have many big problems like other countries did. They also didn't try to force their religion on other people, so the people they ruled over were happier. 

But Britain had a secret weapon too. They used something called the debt market to get money for their wars. They promised people that if they gave them money, they would get it back with extra money if Britain won the war. This helped them have more money for their army than other countries did. Because of all these things, Britain became very powerful and was able to control many lands.
story.70:
Long ago, France and England were rivals. England was able to spend more money on its military because it used the debt markets to fund its wars. France, on the other hand, went bankrupt because it couldn't keep up with England's modern ways of raising money. 

Many years ago, people in Europe wanted to find a new route to India. They needed spices to preserve their meat, and they wanted luxury goods. The Ottoman Turks had taken over the old route, so they needed a new way. Venice and Genoa were too small to stand up to the Turks, so Spain and Portugal got help from North Europeans and Genoese. The Portuguese were the first to find the sea route to India, followed by the Dutch, English, Danes, and French. Vasco Da Gama was the one who discovered the new route in 1498.
story.71:
Long ago, in the 15th century, Europe was filled with a spirit of change and growth. The economy was booming, and people wanted luxury goods like spices to preserve their meat. But there was a problem - the Ottoman Turks had captured important trade routes, making it hard to reach India. The small cities of Venice and Genoa couldn't stand up to the Turks, so Spain and Portugal asked for help from the North Europeans and the Genoese. 

The Portuguese were the first to find a sea route to India, led by a man named Vasco Da Gama. He discovered the route in 1498 and returned in 1502 to set up trading stations in Calicut, Cochin, and Cannanore. Other Portuguese leaders followed, like Francisco de Almeida and Alfonso de Albuquerque, who captured Goa and persecuted Muslims. Nino da Cunha even moved the capital to Goa and took over Diu and Bassein from Gujarat King Bahadur Shah. It was a time of adventure and discovery, but also of conflict and conquest.
story.72: Long ago, a group of Dutch traders came to India. They formed a company called the United East India Company of the Netherlands. This company had the power to fight wars, make treaties, and build forts. They wanted to trade with the people of India and make a profit.
story.73:
Long ago, the Dutch formed a powerful company called the United East India Company. They had the power to make treaties, build forts, and even wage wars. They came to India in 1602 and started trading.

The English were also ambitious and formed their own company, the English East India Company, in 1600. They had a monopoly to trade in the East Indies for 15 years. They defeated the Portuguese and established their first factory at Surat in 1613. They also secured permission to establish factories at Agra, Ahmedabad, and Broach. They even leased Bombay from Charles II for an annual rent of 10 pounds.
story.74: Long ago, the English wanted to trade with the East Indies. Queen Elizabeth I gave them permission to do so for 15 years. They won battles against the Portuguese and established factories in Surat, Agra, Ahmedabad, and Broach. They also leased Bombay for 10 pounds. Later, they made Madras their headquarters and built Fort William in Calcutta. The Mughal Emperor Farrukhsiyar gave them special privileges. They merged with rival companies to become stronger.
story.75:
Long ago, a powerful Company came to rule over India. They were very rich and had many soldiers to protect their interests. But they were not the only ones who wanted to trade in India. The French also came and started their own Company called Compagnie des Indes Orientales. They built a headquarters in a place called Pondicherry, which was given to them by a governor named Sher Khan Lodi. 

The English and French did not get along and fought many wars in India, just like they did in Europe. They both wanted to protect and expand their businesses. These wars were called the Carnatic wars and there were three of them. The first one started in 1740 and ended in 1748 with a treaty called Aix-La Chapelle. The English and French continued to fight for many years, but eventually, the French lost their power in India. Pondicherry was finally incorporated into the Indian Union in 1954.
story.76: In the land of India, there were two powerful companies, the English and the French. They both wanted to protect and expand their businesses, so they fought three wars called the Carnatic Wars. The first war ended with a treaty, but the second war made the French weaker. The third war was very important and had a big battle called Wandiwash. The English won and the French were only allowed to use their settlements for business, not for building forts.
