bullets.24:
• New trading communities from Europe arrived in India
  • Fierce rivalry began among the European trading communities
  • Portuguese had to give way to more powerful and enterprising competitors
  • Dutch and English had greater resources and more compulsions to expand overseas
  • Dutch and English overcame Portuguese resistance
bullets.25:
• Goa lost its importance as a port after the fall of the Vijayanagara empire
  • Spice trade came under the control of the Dutch
  • Goa was superseded by Brazil as the economic centre of the overseas empire of Portugal
  • In 1683, the Marathas invaded Goa after two naval assaults
  • The coming of the Portuguese marked the emergence of naval power in India
  • The Portuguese ships carried cannon, which was the first step in gaining monopoly over trade with the threat or actual use of force
bullets.26:
• The Portuguese ships carried cannon, which was the first step in gaining monopoly over trade with the threat or actual use of force.
  • The Portuguese declared their intention to abide by no rules except their own and were intent on getting a decisive advantage over the Indians and over the Indian Ocean trading system.
  • In the Malabar of the 16th century, the Portuguese showed military innovation in their use of body armour, matchlock men, and guns landed from the ships.
  • The Portuguese may have contributed by example to the Mughal use of field guns and the ‘artillery of the stirrup’.
  • The Portuguese introduced the system of drilling groups of infantry on the Spanish model in the 1630s as a counter to Dutch pressure.
  • The practice was adopted first by the French and English and later taken up by the Marathas and Sikhs, and such armies of sepoys became new tools of empire in India.
  • The Portuguese were masters of improved techniques at sea.
bullets.27:
• Portuguese ships carried cannon, giving them an advantage in trade.
  • They declared their intention to abide by no rules except their own.
  • They showed military innovation in their use of body armour, matchlock men, and guns landed from the ships.
  • They introduced a system of drilling groups of infantry on the Spanish model.
  • Their multi-decked ships were heavily constructed and designed to carry a heavier armament.
  • Their use of castled prow and stern was a noteworthy method by which to repel or launch boarding parties.
  • They were skilled at organization, creating royal arsenals and dockyards and maintaining a regular system of pilots and mapping.
  • The missionaries and the Church were also teachers and patrons in India of the arts of the painter, carver, and sculptor.
bullets.28:
• The missionaries and the Church were teachers and patrons of arts in India
  • They interpreted Portuguese and European art to India
  • The art of silversmith and goldsmith flourished in Goa
  • Goa became a centre of elaborate filigree work, fretted foliage, and metal work embedding jewels
  • Churches built under the Portuguese have plenty of woodwork, sculpture, and sometimes painted ceilings
  • Dutch Commercial enterprise led them to undertake voyages to the East
  • Cornelis de Houtman was the first Dutchman to reach Sumatra and Bantam in 1596
  • In 1602, the States-General of the Netherlands amalgamated many trading companies into the East India Company of the Netherlands
  • The Dutch founded their first factory in Masulipatnam (in Andhra) in 1605
bullets.29:
• The Dutch founded their first factory in Masulipatnam (in Andhra) in 1605.
  • They established trading centres in different parts of India and became a threat to the Portuguese.
  • They captured Nagapatam near Madras (Chennai) from the Portuguese and made it their main stronghold in South India.
  • The Dutch established factories on the Coromandel coast, in Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh, Bengal, and Bihar.
  • In 1609, they opened a factory in Pulicat, north of Madras.
  • Their other principal factories in India were at Surat (1616), Bimlipatam (1641), Karaikal (1645), Chinsura (1653), Baranagar, Kasimbazar (near Murshidabad), Balasore, Patna, Nagapatam (1658), and Cochin (1663).
  • They participated in the redistributive or carrying trade, taking various articles and merchandise from India to the islands of the Far East.
  • They carried indigo, textiles, silk, saltpetre, opium, and rice from different parts of India.
bullets.30:
• Anglo-Dutch rivalry posed a challenge to Dutch commercial interests
  • Commercial rivalry turned into warfare
  • Dutch massacred ten Englishmen and nine Japanese at Amboyna in 1623
  • Rivalry intensified after the incident
  • Both parties came to a compromise in 1667
  • British withdrew claims on Indonesia and Dutch retired from India
  • Dutch monopolised trade in black pepper and spices
  • Dutch traded in silk, cotton, indigo, rice, and opium
  • Dutch got drawn into trade of the Malay Archipelago
bullets.31:
• The Dutch got drawn into the trade of the Malay Archipelago.
  • In the third Anglo-Dutch War (1672–74), communications between Surat and the new English settlement of Bombay got cut.
  • Three homebound English ships were captured in the Bay of Bengal by the Dutch forces.
bullets.32:
• The Battle of Hooghly in November 1759 resulted in the defeat of the Dutch
  • The defeat dealt a crushing blow to Dutch ambitions in India
  • The Dutch were more interested in trade than empire building in India
  • Their main commercial interest was in the Spice Islands of Indonesia
  • The English formed a company called the 'Governor and Company of Merchants of London trading into the East Indies' in 1600
  • The company was granted exclusive trading rights by Queen Elizabeth I
bullets.33:
• Initially, a monopoly of 15 years was granted to the English East India Company
  • In May 1609, the monopoly was extended indefinitely by a fresh charter
  • The Dutch were more interested in the East Indies, so the English turned to India for trade
  • Captain Hawkins arrived in the court of Jahangir in April 1609 to establish a factory at Surat
  • The mission was unsuccessful due to opposition from the Portuguese, and Hawkins left Agra in November 1611
  • The English started trading at Masulipatnam in 1611 and established a factory there in 1616
  • Captain Thomas Best defeated the Portuguese in the sea off Surat in 1612
  • Jahangir granted permission to the English in early 1613 to establish a factory at Surat under Thomas Aldworth
bullets.34:
• Sir Thomas Roe came as an accredited ambassador of James I to the court of Jahangir in 1615
  • He stayed there till February 1619
  • He was unsuccessful in concluding a commercial treaty with the Mughal emperor
  • He secured a number of privileges, including permission to set up factories at Agra, Ahmedabad, and Broach
  • The English company had to contend with the Portuguese and the Dutch in the beginning
  • Bombay was gifted to King Charles II by the King of Portugal as dowry when Charles married the Portuguese princess Catherine in 1662
  • Bombay was given over to the East India Company on an annual payment of 10 pounds only in 1668
  • Bombay was made the headquarters by shifting the seat of the Western Presidency from Surat to Bombay in 1687
  • There was tacit peace between the English and the Portuguese now
bullets.35:
• The Dutch agreed not to interfere with the English company's trade in India
  • The English company's position was improved by the 'Golden Farman' issued by the Sultan of Golconda in 1632
  • The English earned the privilege of trading freely in the ports of Golconda on a payment of 500 pagodas a year
  • Francis Day received permission to build a fortified factory at Madras in 1639
  • Madras later became the Fort St. George and replaced Masulipatnam as the headquarters of the English settlements in south India
  • The English started factories at Hariharpur in the Mahanadi delta and at Balasore in 1633
  • Bengal was a large and rich province in India, advanced in trade and commerce
bullets.36:
• English merchants saw commercial and political control over Bengal as an attractive proposition
  • Bengal was an important province of the Mughal empire
  • Shah Shuja, the subahdar of Bengal, allowed the English to trade in Bengal in return for an annual payment of Rs 3,000
  • Factories in Bengal were started at Hooghly (1651) and other places like Kasimbazar, Patna, and Rajmahal
  • Company's business was obstructed by customs officers who asked for payment of tolls
  • Company wanted a fortified settlement at Hooghly to use force if necessary
  • William Hedges appealed to Shaista Khan for redressal of the grievance
  • Hostilities broke out between the English and the Mughals
bullets.37:
• Hostilities broke out between the English and the Mughals after an unsuccessful appeal for redressal of grievances.
  • Hooghly was sacked by the imperial Mughals in October 1686.
  • The English retaliated by capturing the imperial forts at Thana, raiding Hijli, and storming the Mughal fortifications at Balasore.
  • The English were forced to leave Hooghly and were sent to an unhealthy location at the mouth of River Ganga.
  • Job Charnock, a company agent, started negotiations with the Mughals to return to a place called Sutanuti.
  • Charnock signed a treaty with the Mughals in February 1690, and returned to Sutanuti in August 1690.
  • An English factory was established on February 10, 1691, with an imperial farman permitting the English to "continue contentedly their trade in Bengal" on payment of Rs 3,000 a year in lieu of all dues.
  • A zamindar in Bardhaman district, Sobha Singh, rebelled, giving the English the pretext to fortify their settlement at Sutanuti in 1696.
bullets.38:
• A zamindar in Bardhaman district, Sobha Singh, rebelled, giving the English the pretext to fortify their settlement at Sutanuti in 1696.
  • In 1698, the English bought the zamindari of the three villages of Sutanuti, Gobindapur, and Kalikata (Kalighat) from their owners on payment of Rs 1,200.
  • The fortified settlement was named Fort William in the year 1700 and became the seat of the eastern presidency (Calcutta) with Sir Charles Eyre as its first president.
  • In 1715, an English mission led by John Surman secured three famous farmans from the Mughal emperor Farrukhsiyar, giving the Company many valuable privileges in Bengal, Gujarat and Hyderabad.
  • The farmans exempted the Company’s imports and exports from additional customs duties in Bengal, except for the annual payment of 3,000 rupees as settled earlier.
  • The Company was permitted to issue dastaks (passes) for the transportation of goods and rent more lands around Calcutta.
bullets.39:
• The East India Company was permitted to issue dastaks (passes) for the transportation of goods.
  • The Company was permitted to rent more lands around Calcutta.
  • In Hyderabad, the Company retained its existing privilege of freedom from duties in trade and had to pay the prevailing rent only for Madras.
  • In Surat, for an annual payment of 10,000 rupees, the East India Company was exempted from the levy of all duties.
  • The coins of the Company minted at Bombay were to have currency throughout the Mughal empire.
  • The English East India Company managed to earn a number of trading concessions in Bengal from the Mughal authority by means of flattery and diplomacy.
  • The East India Company was established in 1600.
  • William Hawkins arrived at Jahangir’s court in 1609.
  • Captain Middleton obtained the permission of the Mughal governor of Surat to trade there in 1611.
  • A permanent factory of East India Company was established at Surat in 1613.
bullets.40:
• 1613: A permanent factory of East India Company is established at Surat.
  • 1615: Sir Thomas Roe, the ambassador of King James I, arrives at Jahangir’s court.
  • By 1618, the ambassador succeeds in obtaining two farmans confirming free trade with exemption from inland tolls.
  • 1616: The Company establishes its first factory in the south in Masulipatnam.
  • 1632: The Company gets the golden farman from the Sultan of Golconda ensuring safety and prosperity of their trade.
  • 1633: The Company establishes its first factory in east India in Hariharpur, Balasore (Odisha).
  • 1639: The Company gets the lease of Madras from a local king.
  • 1651: The Company is given permission to trade at Hooghly (Bengal).
  • 1662: The British King, Charles II, is given Bombay as dowry for marrying a Portuguese princess (Catherine of Braganza).
  • 1667: Aurangzeb gives the English a farman for trade in Bengal.
  • 1691: The Company gets the imperial order to continue their trade in Bengal in lieu of payment of Rs 3,000 a year.
bullets.41:
• In 1717, the Mughal emperor Farrukhsiyar issues a farman giving the East India Company a large number of trade concessions, known as the Magna Carta of the Company.
  • This farman allowed the Company to establish complete control over India and get rid of competitors.
  • After the English revolution of 1688, a rival company was formed to oppose the monopoly of the East India Company.
  • The two companies were amalgamated in 1708 under the title of 'United Company of Merchants of England Trading to the East Indies'.
  • This was the East India Company, which was to establish British political power in India from 1708 to 1873.
bullets.42:
• The French established their presence in India for trade in the late 16th century.
  • The Compagnie des Indes Orientales (French East India Company) was founded in 1664 by Louis XIV's minister Colbert.
  • The company was granted a 50-year monopoly on French trade in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
  • The French king also granted the company a concession in perpetuity for the island of Madagascar and any other territories it could conquer.
  • The Company tried to revive the colonies of Madagascar but without any success.
  • Francois Caron headed an expedition to India in 1667 and set up a factory in Surat.
  • Mercara, a Persian who accompanied Caron, founded another French factory in Masulipatnam in 1669 after obtaining a patent from the Sultan of Golconda.
bullets.43:
• Mercara, a Persian, founded a French factory in Masulipatnam in 1669 after obtaining a patent from the Sultan of Golconda.
  • In 1673, the French obtained permission from Shaista Khan to establish a township at Chandernagore near Calcutta.
  • Francois Martin was granted a site for a settlement by Sher Khan Lodi, the governor of Valikondapuram, and founded Pondicherry in 1674.
  • Francois Martin replaced Caron as the French governor in the same year.
  • The French company established its factories in other parts of India, particularly in the coastal regions, including Mahe, Karaikal, Balasore, and Qasim Bazar.
  • After taking charge of Pondicherry in 1674, Francois Martin developed it as a place of importance and it became the stronghold of the French in India.
bullets.44:
• The French stronghold in India was Pondicherry.
  • The outbreak of war between the Dutch and the French badly affected the French position in India.
  • The Dutch captured Pondicherry in 1693.
  • The Treaty of Ryswick restored Pondicherry to the French in 1697.
  • The French had to abandon their factories at Surat, Masulipatnam, and Bantam in the early 18th century due to the War of Spanish Succession.
  • Francois Martin, the governor of Pondicherry, died on December 31, 1706.
  • The French company was reorganised as the ‘Perpetual Company of the Indies’ in 1720.
bullets.45:
• Lenoir and Dumas were active and wise governors of the French company between 1720 and 1742.
  • The French possession of Mauritius and Reunion in the southern Indian Ocean backed French India.
  • The British and French came to India for trading purposes but were ultimately drawn into the politics of India.
  • The Anglo-French rivalry in India reflected the traditional rivalry of England and France throughout their histories.
  • The rivalry in the form of three Carnatic wars decided that the English were to become masters of India.
  • The political situation in south India was uncertain and confused in 1740.
bullets.46:
• In 1740, the political situation in south India was uncertain and confused.
  • Nizam Asaf Jah of Hyderabad was old and fully engaged in battling the Marathas in the western Deccan while his subordinates were speculating upon the consequences of his death.
  • To the south of his kingdom lay the Coromandel Coast without any strong ruler to maintain a balance of power.
  • The decline of Hyderabad was the signal for the end of Muslim expansionism and the English adventurers got their plans ready.
  • The Maratha kingdom of Tanjore provided the Peshwa of Pune an excuse for interference whenever he pleased.
  • The first Carnatic War (1740-48) was fought in the region known as Carnatic, which was the name given by the Europeans to the Coromandel Coast and its hinterland.
bullets.47:
• The First Carnatic War was an extension of the Anglo-French War in Europe
  • The war was caused by the Austrian War of Succession
  • The English navy under Barnet seized some French ships to provoke France
  • France retaliated by seizing Madras in 1746 with the help of the fleet from Mauritius
  • The First Carnatic War ended in 1748 when the Treaty of Aix-La Chapelle was signed
  • Madras was handed back to the English under the terms of the treaty
  • The French got their territories in North America in exchange
  • The Battle of St. Thome was fought between the French forces and the forces of Anwaruddin, the Nawab of Carnatic
  • The English appealed for help to Anwaruddin during the battle
bullets.48:
• Captain Paradise led a small French army to defeat the Indian army under Mahfuz Khan at St. Thome on the banks of the River Adyar.
  • This revealed that a small disciplined army could easily defeat a much larger Indian army.
  • The importance of naval force in the Anglo-French conflict in the Deccan was brought out.
  • The Second Carnatic War was caused by rivalry in India and Dupleix's desire to increase French power and influence in southern India.
  • The death of Nizam-ul-Mulk and the release of Chanda Sahib by the Marathas provided the opportunity for Dupleix to interfere in local dynastic disputes to defeat the English.
bullets.49:
• Opposition to Nasir Jung's accession to the throne of Hyderabad by Muzaffar Jung
  • Chanda Sahib's resentment towards the appointment of Anwaruddin Khan as the Nawab of Carnatic
  • French supported Muzaffar Jang and Chanda Sahib, while English supported Nasir Jang and Anwaruddin
  • Defeat and killing of Anwaruddin at the Battle of Ambur in 1749
  • Muzaffar Jang became the subahdar of Deccan and Dupleix was appointed governor of Mughal territories south of River Krishna
  • French army under Bussy stationed at Hyderabad to secure French interests
bullets.50:
• A French army under Bussy was stationed at Hyderabad to secure French interests there.
  • Territories near Pondicherry and also some areas on the Orissa coast (including Masulipatnam) were ceded to the French.
  • Robert Clive attacked and captured Arcot with a force of 210 men in August 1751.
  • Chanda Sahib failed to get back the fort of Arcot even after a siege of 53 days.
  • Mysore, Tanjore, and the Maratha chief, Morari Rao, came to the aid of Trichinopoly and Clive and Stringer Lawrence.
  • Trichinopoly was first relieved of its siege, while General Law of France with Chanda Sahib remained cooped up in the island of Srirangam.
bullets.51:
• Trichinopoly was relieved of its siege
  • General Law of France and Chanda Sahib were cooped up in the island of Srirangam
  • They surrendered in June 1752
  • Chanda Sahib was executed by Muhammad Ali
  • The British did not interfere
  • Joseph Francis Dupleix was born in 1697
  • He got a high post at Pondicherry in 1720
  • He made a lot of money by private trade
  • In 1741, he was appointed as the Director-General of French colonies in India
  • He was conferred the title of Nawab by the Mughal emperor and the subahdar of Deccan, Muzzaffar Jang
bullets.52:
• Dupleix was conferred the title of Nawab by the Mughal emperor and the subahdar of Deccan, Muzzaffar Jang.
  • Historians believe that Dupleix possessed qualities of an administrator, a diplomat, and a leader with political insight and a broad vision.
  • In 1741, Dupleix became the Governor-General of Pondicherry.
  • Pondicherry faced several problems such as Maratha invasion, famine, uncultivated land, and chaotic conditions in the Carnatic.
  • The Directors of the Company sought a drastic cut in expenditure of the French East India Company, owing to the priority given to the French colonies in North America.
  • Dupleix reduced public expenditure, despite opposition from his council, and balanced income and expenditure, coupled with a cut on salaries of officers.
  • Dupleix disobeyed the directors on the matter of fortification of settlements and enhanced the defences of Pondicherry, even spending a large sum from his personal wealth.
  • Dupleix made Pondicherry the emporium of commerce in south India by taking practical steps to develop the trade of the colony.
bullets.53:
• Dupleix made Pondicherry the emporium of commerce in south India
  • He took practical steps to develop the trade of the colony
  • The Directors of the Company praised Dupleix for taking the right decisions, even in contradiction of the directors
  • Dupleix used the Nawab of Carnatic to forbid the English from waging war in his territories
  • He promised the nawab Madras after the English got defeated
  • But Dupleix did not give Madras to the nawab and even defeated him at St. Thome (1746)
  • Dupleix convinced Admiral La Bourdonnais to break promises made to the English
bullets.54:
• Dupleix convinced his subordinate to do what was considered unethical in general terms, but best suited for one’s nation.
  • Dupleix was the first European to interfere in the internal politics of the Indian rulers.
  • Dupleix supported Muzzaffar Jang for Hyderabad and Chanda Sahib for Carnatic, and his candidates emerged successful.
  • Dupleix was the originator of the practice of subsidiary alliance in India.
  • Dupleix was recalled in 1754 due to the initial defeat of the French army in the Second Carnatic War and the heavy cost incurred by the company due to Dupleix’s political decisions.
  • The recall of Dupleix by the directors was a result of a compromise between France and England over issues in America.
bullets.55:
• Many historians consider the recall of Dupleix a blunder due to a compromise between France and England over issues in America.
  • Dupleix had weaknesses, including an over-sanguine temperament, autocratic behavior, and a lack of action.
  • The French failed to capture Trichinopoly due to Dupleix's plans not being turned into action by his commanders.
  • The French authorities recalled Dupleix in 1754 due to heavy financial losses.
  • Godeheu succeeded Dupleix as the French governor general in India and adopted a policy of negotiations with the English.
  • Godeheu concluded a treaty with the English.
bullets.56:
• Godeheu adopted a policy of negotiations with the English.
  • Godeheu concluded a treaty with the English.
  • The English and the French agreed not to interfere in India.
bullets.57:
• Godeheu adopted a policy of negotiations with the English and concluded a treaty with them.
  • The English and the French agreed not to interfere in the quarrels of native princes.
  • Each party was left in possession of the territories actually occupied by them at the time of the treaty.
  • The fear of serious repercussions in America prompted the French to suspend hostilities in India.
  • The countenance of Indian authority was no longer necessary for European success.
  • Indian authority itself was becoming dependent on European support.
  • Muhammad Ali in the Carnatic and Salabat Jang in Hyderabad became clients rather than patrons.
  • The Third Carnatic War (1758-63) started when Austria wanted to recover Silesia in 1756, and Britain and France were once again on opposite sides.
  • In 1758, the French army under Count de Lally captured the English forts of St. David and Vizianagaram.
bullets.58:
• English became offensive and inflicted heavy losses on the French fleet under Admiral D’Ache at Masulipatnam.
  • The decisive battle of the Third Carnatic War was won by the English on January 22, 1760 at Wandiwash (or Vandavasi) in Tamil Nadu.
  • General Eyre Coote of the English totally routed the French army under Count Thomas Arthur de Lally and took Bussy as prisoner.
  • Pondicherry was gallantly defended by Lally for eight months before he surrendered on January 16, 1761.
  • With the loss of Jinji and Mahe, the French power in India was reduced to its lowest.
  • The Treaty of Peace of Paris (1763) restored to the French their factories in India.
  • The French political influence disappeared after the war.
bullets.59:
• French, Portuguese, and Dutch confined themselves to small enclaves and commerce in India
  • English became the supreme European power in the Indian subcontinent
  • Dutch were already defeated in the Battle of Bidara in 1759
  • Battle of Plassey in 1757 is usually regarded as the decisive event for British rule over India
  • Victory of British forces over French forces at Wandiwash in 1760 was a turning point for control of the subcontinent
  • Victory at Wandiwash left the English East India Company with no European rival in India
  • English received supplies of food and money from Bengal, recruits of men from Europe, and grain from their northern settlements
  • French could receive nothing but what came to them laboriously by land
bullets.60:
• Coote established military superiority over Lally in the field and hemmed him within the walls of Pondicherry.
  • Natives served in both armies as sepoys in the Battle of Wandiwash.
  • The fall of India to European invaders was inevitable, regardless of which side won.
  • There was a lack of sensitivity to geopolitics and foresight on the part of native rulers.
  • The English company was a private enterprise, creating enthusiasm and self-confidence among the people.
  • The French company was a State concern.
bullets.61:
• The French company was a State concern, controlled and regulated by the French government.
  • The English navy was superior to the French navy, cutting off the vital sea link between French possessions in India and France.
  • The English held Calcutta, Bombay, and Madras, while the French had only Pondicherry.
  • The French subordinated their commercial interest to territorial ambition, resulting in a shortage of funds.
  • The British never neglected their commercial interests, maintaining sound financial condition to help them in wars.
  • The superiority of commanders in the British camp was a major factor in their success in India.
bullets.62:
• Painted cloths, prints, silks, and dyes were much desired fabrics.
  • These textiles were in demand not only in Europe but also in other parts of Asia.
  • Indians had traded in textiles for centuries before the Europeans arrived.
  • Indian cotton was popular in China, Japan, and the Indonesian archipelago for its light weight, yet strong qualities.
  • The Dutch, English, and French acquired materials from India not only for their home countries but also for transport to Malacca or Java, where they were traded for spices.
bullets.63:
• French had coloured patterned handkerchiefs specially woven for particular island markets in the 18th century
  • Trade in textiles and spices was accompanied by trade in slaves
  • Trade between Europe and Asia helped to sustain slavery
  • French ships took European goods to Asia and acquired cowry shells and Indian textiles
  • Traders exchanged these goods in Africa for slaves, who were sent to the colonies of France in the Americas
  • Sugar and other goods from the Americas were loaded on board and shipped back to France to complete the circle
  • The French East India Company entered an already well-established, complex economic system in India
  • The economic system was an intricate network of production, negotiation, delivery, and distribution
bullets.64:
• Indian merchants ran large commercial fleets and shore-based businesses.
  • Weavers and merchants worked with overland freight operators and brokers, who worked with exporters and ship owners.
  • Agents had to negotiate with local state officials for commercial privileges.
  • European traders had to learn established rules and practices and collaborate with indigenous envoys.
  • The factories of all European trading groups were in practically the same places.
  • At the peak of Indian trade, demand for Indian goods exceeded supply by weavers and artisans.
  • Initially, there was no serious rivalry.
  • As the Dutch, English, and French grew more competitive, the English were able to expand their factory outposts to larger industrial towns under their jurisdiction.
bullets.65:
• Gradually, commercial strongholds turned into political enclaves in India.
  • The English were able to expand and consolidate their power and control all over India.
  • The Danish East India Company was established in 1616.
  • The Danes founded a factory at Tranquebar near Tanjore in 1620.
  • The Danish factories were not important at any time and were sold to the British government in 1845.
  • The Danes are better known for their missionary activities than for commerce.
  • England emerged as the most powerful and successful European nation in India by the end of the 18th century.
bullets.66:
• The English East India Company was formed through amalgamation of several rival companies at home.
  • The company was controlled by a board of directors whose members were elected annually.
  • Shareholders of the company exercised considerable influence, as the votes could be bought and sold through purchase of shares.
  • The trading companies of France and Portugal were largely owned by the State.
  • The nature of French and Portuguese trading companies was feudalistic.
  • In the French company, the monarch had more than 60 per cent share and its directors were nominated by the monarch from the shareholders.
  • Shareholders took very little interest in promoting the prosperity of the company because the State guaranteed a dividend to the shareholders.
bullets.67:
• The English East India Company was controlled by a board of directors elected annually
  • Shareholders of the company had considerable influence as votes could be bought and sold through purchase of shares
  • French and Portuguese trading companies were largely owned by the State
  • The French company had the monarch as the majority shareholder and directors were nominated by the monarch
  • Shareholders of French and Portuguese companies took little interest in promoting the prosperity of the company as the State guaranteed a dividend
  • Between 1725 and 1765, there was no meeting of shareholders in the French company and it was managed as a department of the State
  • The Royal Navy of Britain was the largest and most advanced of its times
  • The British were able to defeat the Portuguese and French in India due to strong and fast movement of naval ships
  • The English learnt from the Portuguese the importance of an efficient navy and improved their own fleet technologically
  • The Industrial Revolution started in England in the early 18th century with the invention of new machines
  • These machines greatly improved production in the fields of textiles, metallurgy, steam power, and agriculture
bullets.68:
• The Industrial Revolution started in England in the early 18th century
  • New machines like the spinning Jenny, steam engine, and power loom greatly improved production in textiles, metallurgy, steam power, and agriculture
  • The Industrial Revolution reached other European nations late, helping England maintain its hegemony
  • British soldiers were disciplined and well-trained, with strategists as commanders
  • Technological developments equipped the military well, enabling smaller groups to defeat larger armies
  • Britain witnessed stable government with efficient monarchs, except for the Glorious Revolution of 1688
